titles.title: A bill to amend the Small Business Act to expand intellectual property education and training for small businesses, and for other purposes.

action.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship.

calendar.text: Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship. Ordered to be reported without amendment favorably.

action.text: Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship. Reported by Senator Risch without amendment. Without written report.

calendar.text: Placed on Senate Legislative Calendar under General Orders. Calendar No. 347.

vote.text: Passed Senate without amendment by Voice Vote.

action.text: Message on Senate action sent to the House.
Mr. Chabot moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on S. 791.

vote.text: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.

action.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
By Senator Risch from Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship filed written report. Report No. 115-435.

bill.summary:
Small Business Innovation Protection Act of 2017
(Sec. 4) This bill directs the Small Business Administration to develop partnership agreements that provide for:
development of high-quality training for small businesses related to domestic and international protection of intellectual property, leveraging of training materials already developed for the education of inventors and small businesses, and participation of a nongovernmental organization. These agreements must also provide training:
through electronic resources, including Internet-based webinars; and at physical locations, including a small business development center (SBDC) and the headquarters or a regional office of the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office. (Sec. 5) The bill amends the Small Business Act to require services at an SBDC to include training, in person or through a website, relating to:
domestic and international intellectual property protections, and how those protections should be considered in the business plans and growth strategies of small businesses.
